docs.lead_paragraph: A new study from Yale suggests that drug addiction should be thought of as a developmental disorder, because the changing circuitry of teenagers' brains appears to leave them especially vulnerable to the effects of drugs and alcohol. Dr. R. Andrew Chambers of the Yale School of Medicine, lead author of the article, said addictive drugs worked by stimulating parts of the brain that are changing rapidly in adolescence.

headline.main: Drug Addiction as a Developmental Disorder

docs.abstract: Dr R Andrew Chambers, Yale School of Medicine researcher, publishes review in American Journal of Psychiatry that looks at results of 140 tests about teens and drugs and determines age group that has developmental susceptibility to drugs; three aspects of teenage brain functioning are particularly influenced, as they are not completely developed; attraction to novelty, interest in sex and less than adult levels of judgement abilities all combine to make young people more likely to experiment with and become involved with drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women appear to bear up better than men under the effects of sleep deprivation, researchers have found. The findings, presented last week at a meeting of the Endocrine Society in Philadelphia, grew out of a larger study into how well people function when they are deprived of sleep.
docs.abstract: Penn State University College of Medicine study, led by Dr Alexandros N Vgontzas and presented to Endocrine Society Philadelphia meeting, shows women fair better than men when sleep deprived; wake time alertness appears equal between sexes, but women utilize shorter sleep time more effectively and experience better quality sleep; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A recent study suggests an eyebrow-raising approach to fighting smoking. The government, the study says, should consider allowing smokers to buy inhalers that will give them pure shots of nicotine. The inhalers might substantially reduce the damage to public health caused by smoking tobacco, says the study, which appears in the current issue of Tobacco Control.
docs.abstract: Dr Walton Sumner II of Washington University School of Medicine in St Louis authors report in Tobacco Control that suggests allowing smokers to use inhalers with pure shots of nicotine to limit public health issues; urges more study be done on inhalers before public availability; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found the first physical clue to the cause of restless leg syndrome, a condition that disturbs the sleep of millions of Americans. The syndrome, which causes sufferers to move their legs frequently to avoid unpleasant sensations like tingling and throbbing, particularly at night, has sometimes been considered psychological.

headline.main: Legs That Go Kick in the Night

docs.abstract: Dr James Connor, Penn State College of Medicine researcher, shares findings at Association of Professional Sleep Societies that link restless legs syndrome with iron deficiency in cells in brain; study finds that iron supplements temporarily relieve symptoms; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Suburbanites are more likely than people in cities or the countryside to turn to complementary or alternative medical remedies to help with pain, according to a study in the current issue of The American Journal of Public Health. The study was led by Dr. April Hazard Vallerand of the Wayne State University College of Nursing in Detroit.
docs.abstract: Study, led by Dr April Hazard Vallerand of Wayne State University College of Nursing in Detroit and published in American Journal of Public Health, finds 30% of individuals who use alternative therapies to deal with pain do not discuss personal remedy with their doctor; demographically, 82% of suburban dwellers have tried alternate therapies while 77% of city residents and 58% of rural residents have also used them; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Gene Rohrer, a professional accompanist, plays a C major scale in the back room of a medical suite near Lincoln Center, even the untrained ear can tell that something is off. The untrained eye notices his ring finger curling stiffly to let the others pass. But it all goes by so quickly that one might not be sure. The piano, however, knows very precisely what Mr. Rohrer's fingers just did.

headline.main: Video-Computer Combo Helps Pianists Compensate for Stress Injury

docs.abstract: Yamaha Disklavier, $57,000 grand piano synchronized to video and computer, allows physical therapists to help pianists suffering from often career-ending focal dystonia; aggravated by repetitive movement, condition is primarily neurological; sufferers were often placed in retraining program prior to this technology; Disklavier has helped professional accompanist Gene Rohrer, working with physical therapist Dr Kathleen Riley, to see and understand changes in his execution and clarity, allowing him to heal and improve ability; drawings; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Ina May's Guide to Childbirth,'' by Ina May Gaskin. Bantam Books, $14.95. ''The Pregnancy Journal,'' by Dr. A. Christine Harris. Chronicle Books, $18.95. Each woman responds to giving birth in her unique way, writes the renowned midwife Ina May Gaskin in her celebration of the process of childbirth, ''and how very wide-ranging that way can be.'' Her book is a combination of advice on how to have a healthy, joyful childbirth, and of inspirational birthing stories.

headline.main: Pregnancy and Childbirth: More Than How-To Guides

docs.abstract: Midwife Ina May's Guide to Childbirth is her celebration of birth process, inspired by work at Farm Midwifery Center in Summertown, Tennessee; recognizes power of women in childbirth without technological influence; Dr A Christine Harris book Pregnancy Journal gives day-to-day guide for mothers-to-be; chronicles fetal milestones and gives helpful advice for mothers during pregnancy and after baby is born; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vacations can bring out the best and the worst in people. Although everyone may be intent on having fun and relaxing, things inevitably happen to interfere with that goal. Some things are beyond one's control: traffic, long lines, bad weather, canceled flights, automobile breakdowns, sick children, disappointing accommodations, advance reservations that mysteriously disappear. Or there may be disagreements over what or how to pack, when or where to eat, where to spend the night or how to spend the day. Then there are those children who seem to sense their parents' vulnerability and choose trips, especially long car trips, to settle the score with siblings.

headline.main: Keeping Vacation the Break It's Supposed to Be

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses how to keep vacations fun, relaxing and stress free; recommends advance planing; advice on car and airplane trips; adequate training for active vacations and tips to help tourists sleep better in unfamiliar environments are discussed; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps to some people, the strangest aspect of the recent outbreak of monkeypox spread by exotic animals was the idea that someone would want to have a Gambian rat as a pet. But veterinarians, pet experts and anthropologists say they have seen far stranger choices. Even ugly, dangerous and distinctly uncuddly creatures like a tarantula or a horned toad can elicit an emotional response from some people.

headline.main: Cute but Wild: The Perilous Lure of Exotic Pets

docs.abstract: Recent outbreak of monkeypox transmitted by prairie dogs has raised questions as to why people keep exotic pets; Jennifer R Wolch, University of Southern California geography professor, explains ownership of wild animals represents power in many cultures; notes exotic animals were also often kept as sign of wealth and power in past; some examples cited; some feel today's exotic pet owners might be motivated by animal's unpredictability, shock value to others or sense of power over mastering something that is inherently wild; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For most of his life, John Smythe of Glen Rock, N.J., struggled with a hot temper during day and insomnia at night. He thought of these problems as family traits; his parents had them, too. But two years ago his internist told him that they were signs of clinical depression. ''A chill went down my spine,'' recalled Mr. Smythe, 60, who runs a small business. ''Depression to me was somebody walking around moping, sort of withdrawn. It never occurred to me that there could be other symptoms.''

headline.main: For Depression, the Family Doctor May Be the First Choice but Not the Best

docs.abstract: National Institute of Mental Health study, led by Harvard Dr Ronald Kessler, finds only 40% of people treated for depression receive adequate care; shows 70% of all cases are treated by family practitioners, many of whom have limited time and limited training; Dr John F Greden, University of Michigan Depression Center director, advises individuals suffering with depression should seek out mental health professionals, just as they would seek out any medical specialist for specific health problems; study recognizes that general doctors who form relationships with psychiatrists and psychologists provide better care for depression; photos (M)
